Although we appreciate Judge Morris A. Soper's venerable
frankness, we fear that his honest search for a solution to the
current conflict between national security and academic freedom has
led him into an intellectual dead-end.
If we interpret the Judge's recent remarks correctly, he is convinced that professors are akin to the clergy in that they are "members of a sacred order"; this membership imposes a heavy responsibility upon the professor, not the least part of which is that "he is
not free to speak unless he is sure he is right"; he concludes that if
the professor gives evidence of a neglect of this responsibility, his
colleagues and, ultimately, the University "owe it to ... the academic
world to expose the error of ways."
Herein lies the impasse. Universities are dedicated to the search
for truth, for the "right." There is no 'other justification for their
existence. Has our hysterical scramble for security so blinded us that
we no longer consider this a valid assumption? Would Judge Soper
lave us use that for which we labor, that which we have not yet found,
as the standard for judging the utterances of those who labor? This
seems to be the absurdity to which Judge Soper's srgument is reduced.
Because we are still convinced that security can only be preserved by complete freedom of thought and expression, despite the
present concern over "a clear and present danger," and because we
are still dedicated to the assumption that truth will not• be found
in agreement and conformity but must be sought in the lonely confines
of a mind free from authoritarian restrictions, we can not accept
Judge Soper's conclusion.
That "a clear and present danger exists," we do not deny. We
should like to suggest, however, that it is not necessarily represented
by the Communists and their sympathizers. Henry Steele Commager
(professor of history at Columbia University), in his article entitled
'Is Freedom Really Necessary" published this month by the Saturday
Review, has pointed out a second alternative. Professor Commager
asks us first to "fasten our attention on consequences" when considering the conflict between freedom and security. "What happens," he

judge Soper, We Disagree..The Strategy Of Classroom Performance
Although we appreciate Judge Morris A. Soper's venerable
frankness, we fear that his honest search for a solution to the
current conflict between national security and academic freedom has
led him into an intellectual dead-end.
If we interpret the Judge's recent remarks correctly, he is convinced that professors are akin to the clergy in that they are "members of a sacred order"; this membership imposes a heavy responsibility upon the professor, not the least part of which is that "he is
not free to speak unless he is sure he is right"; he concludes that if
the professor gives evidence of a neglect of this responsibility, his
colleagues and, ultimately, the University "owe it to ... the academic
world to expose the error of ways."
Herein lies the impasse. Universities are dedicated to the search
for truth, for the "right." There is no 'other justification for their
existence. Has our hysterical scramble for security so blinded us that
we no longer consider this a valid assumption? Would Judge Soper
lave us use that for which we labor, that which we have not yet found,
